did.abstract: Thomas C. Carpendale's journal describes a trip from New York to London in 1861. Notes in the journal are addressed to Carpendale's friend in Brooklyn, George A. Thorne. The journal also includes illustrations and drawings of sea scenes from the voyage by Carpendale.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transfer from the Brooklyn Museum Library, date unknown. An inscription at the front of the volume reads "Bessie M. Thorne," presumably a relation of George A. Thorne, to whom the text is addressed. The item was officially accessioned in 1985.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single volume.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Thomas Coulson Carpendale was born in the early 1830s. He married Delphine J. Meunier in 1855 and they had three children, Edwin, Emma, and Luce. His friend George A. Thorne lived at 43 Sands Street, Brooklyn.

The Carpendales later settled in Montreal, where they are listed in the 1871 census of Canada. By the 1881 census, Delphine is listed as widowed, but still living in Montreal. In 1892, she and two of her children are listed in a New York City directory living in Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thomas C. Carpendale's journal describes a trip from New York to London in August-September, 1861. Notes in the journal are addressed to Carpendale's friend in Brooklyn, George A. Thorne. The journal also includes illustrations and drawings of sea scenes and animals from the voyage by Carpendale, as well as a map of the ship's route across the Atlantic. There are also excerpts copied from literature, the Bible, and poetry, including verses by Carpendale himself. He also refers to the American Civil War, which had started some months before, as well as Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Carpendale and his family traveled on the ship Adriatic.
